9-2(b)	Employment, social security and social protection law	“processing is necessary for the purposes of carrying out the obligations and exercising specific rights of the controller or of the data subject in the field of employment and social security and social protection law in so far as it is authorised by Union or Member State law or a collective agreement pursuant to Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for the fundamental rights and the interests of the data subject”

9-2(e)	Made public by the data subject	“processing relates to personal data which are manifestly made public by the data subject”

4.2	Objective

With the emergence of the Internet of Things (IoT) and health-related data collecting services, such as fitness trackers, more and more data is being collected in the cloud and shared through the Web.

With the emergence of the Internet of Things (IoT) and health-related data collecting services, such as fitness trackers, more and more data is being collected in the cloud and shared through the Web.
Particularly, the healthcare sector is facing a variety of data governance challenges when it comes to this domain:
Particularly, the healthcare sector is facing a variety of data governance challenges when it comes to this domain:

•	The increasing number of consultation services that are being provisioned through the Web: more and more healthcare services are turning to virtual doctor consultation and remote medical advice to improve patient care and to make healthcare more accessible to everyone (Wang et al., 2020).

•	The increasing number of consultation services that are being provisioned through the Web: more and more healthcare services are turning to virtual doctor consultation and remote medical advice to improve patient care and to make healthcare more accessible to everyone (Wang et al., 2020).

•	The increasing number of consultation services that are being provisioned through the Web: more and more healthcare services are turning to virtual doctor consultation and remote medical advice to improve patient care and to make healthcare more accessible to everyone (Wang et al., 2020).

•	Increasing number of Artificial Intelligence algorithms for healthcare: health-related data is often highly variable and unstructured and as such faces data quality and accuracy problems, which can lead to poor decision making and poor research results (Raghupathi & Raghupathi, 2014).

•	Genomic data: with the introduction of the possibility of sequencing the human genome, genetic data is now available, although the cost and privacy concerns over the processing of these high density datasets are still an important issue and their implications for public health continue to be debated (Belle et al., 2015; Grishin et al., 2018); services such as ancestry.com, which provides information about the genetic and health data of family trees, also bring up the issue of whom has control over the access to such sensitive data.

•	Genomic data: with the introduction of the possibility of sequencing the human genome, genetic data is now available, although the cost and privacy concerns over the processing of these high density datasets are still an important issue and their implications for public health continue to be debated (Belle et al., 2015; Grishin et al., 2018); services such as ancestry.com, which provides information about the genetic and health data of family trees, also bring up the issue of whom has control over the access to such sensitive data.

•	Genomic data: with the introduction of the possibility of sequencing the human genome, genetic data is now available, although the cost and privacy concerns over the processing of these high density datasets are still an important issue and their implications for public health continue to be debated (Belle et al., 2015; Grishin et al., 2018); services such as ancestry.com, which provides information about the genetic and health data of family trees, also bring up the issue of whom has control over the access to such sensitive data.

A possible solution to overcome these challenges can be to give back to the users the control over their health data.

In this specific case study, Semantic Web open standards are going to be used, analysed and extended for the governance of sensitive personal data, such as health and genetic data, and for the management of related GDPR rights.

Although the implementation of Web privacy policy languages  has been achieved successfully in the past, there is a need for a language that can fully align privacy and data protection principles with the governance of access to personal data.

Although the implementation of Web privacy policy languages  has been achieved successfully in the past, there is a need for a language that can fully align privacy and data protection principles with the governance of access to personal data.

Within this framework, the usage of machine-readable policy languages seems to be a perfect fit for the governance of access privileges to personal data resources as well as to support data controllers in the management of their GDPR obligations, as they are flexible, interoperable and can be used to reason over the generated policies to assist with compliance.

Although the implementation of Web privacy policy languages  has been achieved successfully in the past, there is a need for a language that can fully align privacy and data protection principles with the governance of access to personal data.

Thus, in the last few years, especially after the enter into force of the GDPR, we have seen an increase in the development of ontologies and vocabularies to represent concepts related to the data protection domain.

The usage of these policy languages accompanied by GDPR-related ontologies and vocabularies can therefore greatly favour the development of GDPR compliant applications and assist users in the management of their data protection rights.

With massive amounts of data only in the hands of a few stakeholders, censorship, bias and discrimination are subtly entering the Web sphere.

Resistance to censorship and surveillance are two major benefits brought by decentralized systems, in addition to data portability and interoperability, which allow users to control their own data and easily share it between services, without having to recreate it again.

Resistance to censorship and surveillance are two major benefits brought by decentralized systems, in addition to data portability and interoperability, which allow users to control their own data and easily share it between services, without having to recreate it again.

Decentralized systems can be public or private, depending on whether they are open for reading and writing transactions without any access restrictions or whether access to a particular resource depends on prior acceptance by the user.

In the next subsections, decentralized solutions for data governance are going to be briefly described.
4.3.2.1	Blockchain technology
Its main advantages are immutability, resilience, and the lack of a central authority.
Its main advantages are immutability, resilience, and the lack of a central authority.
A key application of blockchains for the data governance domain are the so-called “smart contracts”.

Smart contracts are computer programs that can automatically enforce the terms of a contract and therefore allow for the transactions between the entities involved to be carried out in accordance with the contractual agreement.

Smart contracts are computer programs that can automatically enforce the terms of a contract and therefore allow for the transactions between the entities involved to be carried out in accordance with the contractual agreement.
IPFS is an open source protocol for sharing and storing data on the Web through a distributed file system.

IPFS’s main objectives are to make the Web more efficient, using a distributed network of storage providers to disseminate high volumes of data without duplication; to preserve all versions of files; and to make content persistently available.

IPFS’s main objectives are to make the Web more efficient, using a distributed network of storage providers to disseminate high volumes of data without duplication; to preserve all versions of files; and to make content persistently available.
To accomplish this, IPFS uses hash functions to uniquely identify resources, instead of using an Uniform Resource Locator (URL).
A DHT is therefore a distributed system that maps hashes with files, and it is responsible to replicate this data across all nodes in the system.

A user can either choose to self-host a Pod in its personal server or can rely on a Pod Provider, and Solid applications can read and write data into the Pods according to the Pod owner’s preferences.

With Solid, applications such as Facebook and Twitter would be frontend services that access user’s data, according to the preferences each user establishes for their own Pod, instead of being silos for billions of people’s personal data.

Solid (Solid, 2020) is a Web technology that extends open standards and specifications to build a interoperable platform for decentralized applications that consume linked data.
Solid (Solid, 2020) is a Web technology that extends open standards and specifications to build a interoperable platform for decentralized applications that consume linked data.

This project uses open standards and specifications, such as the Linked Data Platform (Speicher et al., 2015) and the Web Access Control (WebAccessControl, 2016), to support interoperability between applications and enable data portability between servers, thus allowing users to select which services can handle their personal data, to reuse that data across multiple applications and to have their personal data store, the so-called Solid Pod.
